content.description:
Begin up

Five Tree

and start climbing the very wide crack that veers off to the right.
content.location: Located on the lower wall between Five Tree and Pugsley.

content.description: A slabbier and slightly less protected version of Tabby Treat at Suicide Rock.  (Hell, Faith Healer reminded me a bit of Graham Crackers.) Route wanders through the gully and can finish at the sappy tree.  (Tabby Treat also has a tree landmark you can't miss.)  The crack moves to reach the tree are the steepest and involve jamming/chimneying.
content.location: Gully to the left of Norm.  Rap from the tree or venture further on your own adventure to the upper tier.

content.description:
Climbs a long broken crack system in a vague right-facing corner. Gear belay at the top and walk down and right across the ledge above

Leap Year Flake

to reach rap anchors.
content.location:
The first crack system just right of

Norm

.

climbs.name: Pugsley
climbs.fa: (TR): Bob Gaines and Will Kozicki, May, 2016. FLead: Bob Gaines, Todd Gordon, and Rebecca Roscher, September, 2016.

content.description:
This is the steepening slab just left of Mojus- tightly bolted enough to be considered a sport climb. The route gets progressively more difficult at each bolt.

Rap from the 2-bolt anchor, or continue up the upper section of Mojus past 2 more bolts (5.11-) then up and right to a crack (1-inch CD for pro).

From here climb up and right to the Addams Family 2-bolt anchor (100-foot rappel).

climbs.name: Norm
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Dana Adler, Cyndie Bransford, Jim Angione, Brian Haslam, Susan Alford,  March 1995

content.description:
Start up a short section of smooth slab with a jagged crack to reach a small roof/overlap with a fixed pin about 15' up, above which is the first of five bolts. The climb moves slightly right after the second bolt to reach a shallow corner, which is followed up to a small mantleshelf and the third bolt. Above, climb through a lower-angled section before the wall steepens and enjoyable smearing and liebacking on the edge of the flake continues past two more bolts to anchors. The rock is a fine grained gray with the occasional knob, which is a pleasant departure from the more typical oatmeal-colored rock.

This is a fun climb that rarely sees traffic due to it's location on the less popular left side of the DQ Wall. A pleasant area to explore that has an easier and shorter approach than the more frequented right side of the wall. Two stars out of five.
content.protection:
5 bolts (1/2" SS), fixed pin, bolted anchor/rap

Optional 0.5 inch cam to back up the fixed pin
content.location:
This route is located on the far left side of the Dairy Queen Wall about 50' left of

Leap Year Flake

, and is identified as a bolted face climb up the face/arete of a large flake lying against the main formation.

climbs.name: Morticia
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Mike McKay, January 2016

content.description:
This link-up connects the best part of Mojus to finish on the upper half of Addams Family.

Climb a beautiful slab past 2 bolts (5.10b/c; well-protected at the crux) then run it out a bit on easier slab (5.7/8) to a steeper section with 3 closely-spaced bolts (5.10+). At the 5th bolt move right and finish up the left facing corner/crack of Addams Family (5.8).
content.protection: 5 bolts, gear: thin to 1.5 inches. 2-bolt anchor (100 ft.)

climbs.name: The Mojus (aka Slushie)
climbs.fa: Rondo Powell, Joe Bentley and Bob Gaines, 1988

content.description:
This route climbs a smooth slab near the center of the left side and features some difficult smears at the crux.

Not a great route but it's fairly long and offers some good movement throughout it's length. Two stars out of five.
content.protection: 8 bolts, gear to 3 inches, bolted anchor/rap (all bolts are 3/8")
content.location:
Climbs a smooth slab just down and left from

Get Right or Get Left (aka Addams Family)

.

content.description: a fun, knobby finger crack
content.location: This route starts at ground level, and ends on a ledge system near the top.

content.description:
Start this climb as per

Leap Year Flake

, by climbing a thin crack to a prominent undercling flake about 50' up. Once established in the undercling flake head straight up via runout face climbing to the spacious ledge below Pat Adams Dihedral.

Descent is from a bolted anchor about 30' down and right of where the climbs ends. Due to the runout nature of the climbing this route is better suited as a toprope or a lead for those solid at the grade. One star out of five.

Climb a thin crack with face holds for about forty feet, then step left and undercling/lieback a thin flake that curves up and left ending on a large ledge beneath the previously mentioned corner.

Expect fun climbing on high quality rock in a relatively uncrowded area, as this side of the Dairy Queen Wall sees little action. Well worth doing as along with a number of the other routes here. Two stars out of five.
content.location:
This fun and somewhat unique climb is located on the left side of the Dairy Queen Wall more or less directly below the prominent, overhanging corner of

Pat Adams Dihedral

.

climbs.name: Leap of the Imagination
climbs.fa: Jan Tarculas and Chris Miller, March 2020

content.description:
Start just right of a yucca and move up and left into a seam which quickly becomes a crack which is followed to it's end where face climbing past a large grey knob gains an arete.

Climb the arete until able to stem across the wide crack of

Five Tree

to an

adjoining block and climb large features past a loose flake, f

inishing with a short section of thin crack in excellent rock. Two stars out of five.
content.location:
Starts 15 feet right of

Leap Year Flake

next to a yucca and left of

Five Tree

.

content.description:
Climbs a slanting right-facing corner system to cracks and then moves slightly right to finish with the last two bolts on

Leap Erickson

.

Gear belay at the top and walk down and right across the ledge above

Leap Year Flake

to reach rappel anchors.

Mistakenly identified as "

Look Before You Leap

" (which is further right on this same rock) in the Joshua Tree West guidebook.
content.location:
The right-facing corner between

Faith Healer

and

Leap Erickson

.

climbs.name: Leap Erickson
climbs.fa: (TR): Todd Swain, October 1989  FL: Chris Miller,  January 1999

content.description:
Start up a left-slanting ramp to reach a high first bolt, above which some reachy difficult moves lead onto a somewhat low-angled slab. Delicate moves on small, sometimes friable, flakes give way to a steepening wall with small grey knobs and protrusions that provide entertaining climbing.

Gear belay and then walk right to a rap station located 10 meters down and right from the top of

Leap Year Flake

.

Note - a 70 meter rope is needed to TR this route

.
content.protection: 7 bolts (all 1/2" SS), several pieces from 1 - 2 inches for the anchor
content.location:
On the long slabby face just left of

Leap Year Flake

.

climbs.name: Gomez
climbs.fa: (TR) Todd Swain, October 1989, FL: Chris Miller, 1998

content.description:
Climbs a steepening slab to vertical headwall (5.11) before entering a steep but featured crack system (5.8). Angle left to the chain anchors on

Get Right or Get Left

, or gear belay and scramble/climb left to access the anchors to rap (

100' rap!

).

A huge piece of rock has fallen from this route making it much harder than it's original 5.10a rating.

Enjoyable climbing on quality rock, and in a locale that sees little traffic make this a good tick for the grade if in the area. Two stars out of five.
content.location:
Starts just right of

Get Right or Get Left (aka Addams Family)

.

climbs.name: Get Right or Get Left (aka Addams Family)

content.description:
Climb easy terrain to a solitary bolt about 20 feet up then continue up a low-angled slab past a grapefruit-sized knob at the base of a vertical headwall with a featured crack.

Intriguing moves, as well as textbook stopper slots, will be found throughout this section; higher the route follows a crack in a left-facing corner which affords some nice stemmming and thin jamming.

The crack ends about 20 feet below the anchors, and while possible to climb directly, an easier (and safer) alternative is to cut right about 8 feet to reach another crack system leading to the anchor. Bolted anchor/rap.

This is an enjoyable route reminiscent of the featured cracks of the upper Dairy Queen Wall, as well as the Shorter Wall in Rock Garden Valley. Three stars out of five.
content.protection: Bolt (1/2"), gear to 2 inches (especially small to medium wires), bolted anchor/rap (3/8")
content.location:
You'll find this route just up and right from a prominent smooth slab with

The Mojus (aka Slushie)

.

content.description:
Start out of a gully (

Tabby Tree

) and climb the face left of Norm passing along a vertical seam down low; the route stays independent the entire way.

Perhaps worth doing while the rope is hanging there.
content.protection: Toprope from the anchors atop Norm

climbs.name: The Foot Massage
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Dana Adler, Richard White, Cydnie Bransford, Pat Nay, Karen Roseme, March 1995

content.description: Foot Massage starts via some crumbly rock to a bolt ( missing hanger, *small nut to sling*).  Slab climb a weaving path past 3 more bolts to the upper crack.  Easier crack climbing leads to interesting moves surmounting the roof.  Longer than it looks from the ground with some challenging slab moves.  Could use some clean up.
content.protection: 4 bolts (first bolt has a washer, but no hanger). Only the wire of smaller nuts will fit behind the washer! Single set of cams and some small-med nuts.
content.location: Located on the upper buttress left of Norm/Leap Erickson et. al.  The face to crack on the right side of the wall.  Page 332 of JT West.

content.description: This is the left of two approach cracks to gain the upper level routes starting halfway up the face. Not especially exciting but it does provide an alternate approach that goes at an easier grade.
content.location:
The obvious wide crack/gully with a tree just right of

Leap Year Flake

.

content.description:
Climbs a crack to right-facing corner which ends and finishes past some large blocks. Gear belay at the top and walk down and right across the ledge above

Leap Year Flake

to reach rap anchors.
content.location:
The crack just right of

Snake Oil

.

content.description:
A bit of a grindy wide crack.

Grainy and a bit insecure.

Likely mostly top roped.
content.protection: Large cams and secure technique.  Or, a tight top rope.
content.location:
On the far left side of the left side of the Dairy Queen Wall.

Left of Foot Massage.Â  Yeah, that wide crack.
